title: Counter form typeface & legibility testing
content:
Hi all,  
I'm a newbie here, and I hope to generate some discussion and get some feedback on my masters project while I'm here :)

I'm developing a typeface based on the counter forms of letter shapes, in order to test the ability of readers to recognise these first as alphabetic forms, and secondly their ability to decipher and read them. I am not interested in creating a highly readable typeface for common use but rather in testing the readers ability to decipher new letter-shapes based on a subconscious familiarity with the counter-forms.

The typeface is close to the testing phase and I want to create an interview or questionnaire in order to test these theories. I have ideas about how this questionnaire should be constructed but I would really benefit from some specific examples of legibility tests. Although there are alot of references to legibility tests out there I'm having trouble finding actual examples of these tests.

If anyone can provide advice on where to find such test examples it would be greatly appreciated!

Thanks in advance  
Kate
author: Kate Francis Design

![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150217005417im_/http:/typophile.com/files/lint_14_6508.gif)
  
Here is an early draft. This one is a degenerative version, where parts of the counters and ascenders and descenders have been removed. The letter "l" disappears altogether and distinctions between "n" and "h" and "b", "d", "p" and "q" are unclear. This is something I am working on to fix. Also you can see that it is not strictly a counter form typeface as some features such as the dot on "i" and "j" remains.
ps. anyone who can read it wins a prize!

There’s a very fundamental flaw here: you’re only considering the counterforms inside of the letters. The counterforms outside of the letters are just as important, and in the case of some letters, even more important than the interior.

There’s a very fundamental flaw here: Artistic license? I am aware of this however I have made the decision to work with the inner counters only as much as possible. The font is still in development so I hope to deal with some of the legibility issues... things that just happened
like lint. Indeed, you are correct! Its from a Richard Brautigan poem from which the fonts name was decided. Heres the whole thing: **lint** I‘m haunted a little this evening by feelings that have no vocabulary and events that should be explained in dimensions of lint rather than words. I‘ve been examining half scraps of my childhood. they are pieces of distant life that have no form or meaning. they are things that just happened like lint. By Richard Brautigan I found it quite apt.
